front:
joint probability mass function
(pair of random variables)
back: For a pair of random variables $(X,Y)$, the joint probability mass function (PMF) defines the probability that $(X,Y)$ takes on each value $(x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2$, \begin{align*} P_{X,Y} (x,y) &= P\left[ \left\{ s \left| X(s) = x, Y(s) =y \right. \right\} \right] \\ &= P \left[ X=x, Y=y \right]. \end{align*}

front:
joint cumulative distribution function
(pair of random variables)
back: For a pair of random variables $(X,Y)$, the joint cumulative distribution function (CDF) is \begin{align*} F_{XY} (x,y) &= P\left[ \left\{ s \left| X(s) \le x, Y(s) \le y \right. \right\} \right] \\ &= P \left[ X \le x, Y \le y \right]. \end{align*}

front:
joint probability density function
(pair of random variables)
back: For a pair of random variables $(X,Y)$, the joint probability density function (pdf) is \begin{align*} f_{XY} (x,y) &= \frac{\partial^2}{\partial x ~\partial y} F_{XY} (x,y). \end{align*}

front:
marginal probability density function
(pair of random variables)
back: For a pair of random variables $(X,Y)$ with joint pdf $f_{XY} (x,y)$, the marginal density functions of $X$ and $Y$ are the individual pdfs $f_X(x)$ and $f_Y(y)$. They can be calculated from the joint pdf as \begin{align*} f_X(x) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{XY} (x,y) dy , \mbox{ and}\\ f_Y(y) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{XY} (x,y) dx . \end{align*}

For a random vector $\mathbf{X}= \left[X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_{n-1}\right]$, the covariance matrix $K$ is the $n \times n$ matrix whose $i,j$th entry is \begin{align*} \mathbf{K}_{ij} &= \operatorname{Cov}(X_i, X_j) \\ &= E \left(X_i - \mu_i \right) \left(X_j - \mu_j\right). \end{align*}

For jointly distributed random variables $X$ and $Y$, the correlation coefficient is \begin{align*} \rho &= \frac{\operatorname{Cov}(X, Y)}{\sigma_X \sigma_y}, \end{align*} where $\sigma_{X}^{2}$ and $\sigma_{Y}^{2}$ are the variances of $X$ and $Y$.
